title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
JPMorgan has applied to take full control of its securities joint venture in China, in the latest example of a US bank expanding its foothold in the country's financial markets.

The bank said on Thursday that it had handed in an application to Chinese regulators to purchase 100 per cent of the business, up from its current 71 per cent. It is also in the process of buying out the joint venture partner in its China asset management business.

It follows a similar move by Goldman Sachs, which last month won approval from Chinese regulators to take control of its wealth management joint venture with ICBC, one of China's largest banks.

BlackRock, the world's biggest asset manager, has also received permission to start a wealth management joint venture with China Construction Bank and Singapore's state fund Temasek in the country.

Seduced by untapped savings and a growing asset management market, worth an estimated Rmb121.6tn ($18.9tn) last year, Wall Street's most storied firms are embedding themselves more deeply than ever into China.

Go deeper: You can read more on Wall Street's growing love affair with China in this recent big read.

Coronavirus digest

  • The Federal Reserve said it would start selling the corporate bonds and fixed income funds that it bought to stabilise the financial system last year.

  • Deutsche Bank has told its roughly 1,500 US investment bank employees that they must be back in the office by early September.

  • British ministers are struggling to persuade their American counterparts to lift the US coronavirus ban on non-Americans travelling from the UK to the US.

  • Complaints that hundreds of ventilators bought with Narendra Modi's signature Indian recovery fund do not work have stoked worries about the charity's spending.

  • The rapid development of diagnostics to detect Covid-19 will be crucial in keeping on top of outbreaks, variants and flu when it re-emerges.

Follow our live coronavirus blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

‘Meme stock' AMC surges after luring traders with popcorn AMC shares surged as much as 127 per cent to $72.62 on Wednesday after the cinema chain promised to dish out free popcorn to investors, in the latest example of how the “meme trading” frenzy is rippling across Wall Street.

  • Listen: Madison Darbyshire, US investment reporter, talked to the FT News Briefing podcast about the extraordinary run for AMC's shares, which have increased by 3,000 per cent since the start of the year.

Israel opposition leaders agree coalition to oust Netanyahu A coalition anchored by the centrist Yesh Atid party but straddling the far-left Meretz to the ultranationalist Yamina has agreed to form a government in Israel. The agreement could potentially end Benjamin Netanyahu's 12-year reign as prime minister of the Jewish state. There is a sense that things might finally be shifting in Israel, writes international affairs editor David Gardner.

Biden to rebuke Putin over hack of meat processor JBS Joe Biden will rebuke Vladimir Putin over the cyber attack on JBS, the world's biggest meat processor, when the two presidents meet later this month. The US does not rule out retaliating against the perpetrator it suspects is a Russian criminal gang, the White House said on Wednesday.

US wields $2bn tariff threat over digital taxes The US has threatened to slap tariffs on $2bn worth of goods from the UK and five other countries as they argue about how to tax technology companies, a move that risks reigniting transatlantic trade wars unless parties resolve thorny talks over a broader international tax agreement.

Trafigura warned Credit Suisse over Gupta invoice The commodities trader warned Credit Suisse last year that its supply-chain finance funds appeared to contain a suspicious invoice from industrialist Sanjeev Gupta's business empire, according to three people with knowledge of the discussions.

Google boosts Android privacy protections Google is strengthening privacy protections for Android users who want to make it harder for advertisers to track them when they move between apps, as the company tries to counter Apple's image as a better steward of personal data.

Spac promoter Chamath Palihapitiya to target biotech companies The billionaire investor and former Facebook executive is planning to raise $800m for four cash shells that will target biotechnology businesses. The four new Spacs will all use ticker names beginning “DNA” in a partnership with Kishen Mehta, a healthcare-focused portfolio manager at Suvretta Capital Management.

The day ahead

Employment data The ADP national employment report is expected to show private payrolls rose 650,000 in May, after surging by 742,000 in April. The US Labor Department is expected to release initial jobless claims data for the week ended May 29 — it is likely to have risen 390,000. European stocks wavered ahead of the data release.

Broadcom results The semiconductor maker is expected to post a rise in second-quarter revenue, as growing 5G technology adoption increased demand for its chips.

G7 health ministers meet Ahead of next week's G7 summit, the UK is hosting a meeting of health ministers to discuss the global response to the pandemic and distribution of vaccines.

St Petersburg forum The annual gathering was once a regular date for US and European executives, officials and heads of state, but lately it has become a barometer of Russia's soured relations with the west as the list of high-profile foreign attendees shrinks.

What else we're reading

How the US used car market is driving inflation Unusually, officials are watching used car prices closely as an indicator for the future path of inflation. If the price rises spread into other parts of the economy, the US could face a prolonged period of overheating for the first time in decades, posing a challenge for the Federal Reserve and policymakers.

The giant-killer stalking Wall Street With just 22 employees and $240m worth of assets under management, Engine No 1, went up against the mightiest oil company in the US and won three seats on its board, with a mandate to prepare it for a future free of fossil fuel. But as US energy editor Derek Brower and M&A correspondent Ortenca Aliaj explain, Engine No 1 is no fly-by-night outfit.

The Englishman trying to save US bookstores from Amazon The future of the precious bookstore experience is far from assured in the age of Amazon, eBooks and the pervasive strain on physical retailers. A great deal depends on the benign dictator of English-language bookstores, James Daunt. His toughest task: tempting Americans back into Barnes & Noble.

Silicon Valley bets to disrupt traditional finance In the past year the fastest-growing cryptocurrency start-ups have been those aiming to abolish financial intermediaries — such as Uniswap — bringing along a new crop of venture capitalists and producing returns that are the envy of more conservative peers.

How Mali fell from grace Just a decade ago, Mali was held up as a paragon of democratic virtue, following the 1991 coup that overthrew dictator Moussa Traoré. But the African Union's suspension of the country this week provided official, if belated, recognition that a democracy once heralded as a shining example in west Africa is on the ropes.

Put the BBC behind a paywall overseas Funding negotiations are a perennial struggle for the BBC, but the current one has an intriguing twist. It may determine how overseas viewers will bankroll it. Alex Barker asks: will the broadcaster have the firepower to reinvent itself as a streaming service that can attract tens of millions of subscribers outside Britain?
